The vectors $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$ are mutually orthogonal.  There exist scalars $p,$ $q,$ and $r$ such that
\[\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ 7 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = p \mathbf{a} + q \mathbf{b} + r \mathbf{c}.\]Enter the ordered triple $(p,q,r).$
inference:
We are given that $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.$  We are also given that
\begin{align*} \mathbf{v} = \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ 7 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = p \mathbf{a} + q \mathbf{b} + r \mathbf{c} = p \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + q \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix} + r \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}. \end{align*}Taking the dot product of both sides with $\mathbf{a},$ we get
\begin{align*} \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{a} &= (-4)(1) + (7)(1) + (3)(1) \\ &= -4 + 7 + 3 = 6 \\ &= p (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{a}) + q (\mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{a}) + r (\mathbf{c} \cdot \mathbf{a}) \\ &= p (1^2 + 1^2 + 1^2) + q (2(1) + (-3)(1) + 1(1)) + r (4(1) + 1(1) + (-5)(1)) \\ &= 3p + q (0) + r (0) \\ &= 3p. \end{align*}Then $3p = 6,$ so $p = 2.$

Taking the dot product of both sides with $\mathbf{b},$ we get
\begin{align*} \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{b} &= (-4)(2) + (7)(-3) + (3)(1) \\ &= -8 - 21 + 3 = -26 \\ &= p (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b}) + q (\mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{b}) + r (\mathbf{c} \cdot \mathbf{b}) \\ &= p (0) + q (2^2 + (-3)^2 + 1^2) + r (4(2) + 1(-3) + (-5)(1)) \\ &= q (4 + 9 + 1) + r (8 - 3 - 5) \\ &= 14q + 0 \\ &= 14q. \end{align*}Then $14q = -26,$ so $q = -\frac{26}{14} = -\frac{13}{7}.$

Taking the dot product of both sides with $\mathbf{c},$ we get
\begin{align*} \mathbf{v} \cdot \mathbf{c} &= (-4)(4) + (7)(1) + (3)(-5) \\ &= -16 + 7 - 15 = -24 \\ &= p (\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}) + q (\mathbf{b} \cdot \mathbf{c}) + r (\mathbf{c} \cdot \mathbf{c}) \\ &= p (0) + q (0) + r (4^2 + 1^2 + (-5)^2) \\ &= r (16 + 1 + 25) \\ &= 42r. \end{align*}Then $42r = -24,$ so $r = -\frac{24}{42} = -\frac{4}{7}.$

Thus, $(p,q,r) = \left( 2, -\frac{13}{7}, -\frac{4}{7} \right).$
Final Answer: $\boxed{\left( 2, -\frac{13}{7}, -\frac{4}{7} \right)}$ I hope it is correct.

But we can also take advantage of the fact that $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 1 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} 2 \\ -3 \\ 1 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 4 \\ 1 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}$ are mutually orthogonal.

We can take the equation, $\begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ 7 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = p \mathbf{a} + q \mathbf{b} + r \mathbf{c},$ and take the dot product of $\mathbf{a}$ with both sides:
\[\mathbf{a} \cdot \begin{pmatrix} -4 \\ 7 \\ 3 \end{pmatrix} = p \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{a} + q \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} + r \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c}.\]Note that $\mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{b} = \mathbf{a} \cdot \mathbf{c} = 0,$ and we are left with
\[6 = 3a.\]Hence, $a = 2.$
